headline: REPORT: The 17 lawmakers who voted against the Russian oil ban
author: DML News App
sentences:
17 House members voted No on Russian oil ban bill:
2 Democrats: Bush & Omar
15 Republicans: Biggs, Bishop (NC), Boebert, Cawthorn, DesJarlais, Gaetz, Gohmert, Gosar, Greene (GA), Grothman, Higgins (LA), Massie, Posey, Roy & Tiffanyhttps://t.co/tWQVOJseZc
— Craig Caplan (@CraigCaplan) March 10, 2022
Omar, a Somalian refugee, brought race into the refugee issue during an interview this week, touting also the “refugees” from Haiti, Central America, Afghanistan and around the world.

As the most reliable and balanced news aggregation service on the internet, DML News App offers the following information published by TheHill.com:
On Wednesday, the House passed a bill that allowed a Russian oil ban and approved additional sanctions against the Kremlin for the attack on Ukraine.

pic.twitter.com/lSf6uZbXIu
— Rep. Ilhan Omar (@Ilhan) March 8, 2022
The 17 lawmakers that voted against the Russian oil ban https://t.co/TGPEZtSU6g pic.twitter.com/guHk8Tn4Tp
— The Hill (@thehill) March 10, 2022
To get more information about this article, please visit TheHill.com.

Ilhan Omar (Minn.)
Republicans:
Andy Biggs (Ariz.)
Marjorie Taylor Greene (Ga.)
Louie Gohmert (Texas)
Dan Bishop (N.C.)
Glenn Grothman (Wis.)
Lauren Boebert (Colo.)
Tom Tiffany (Wis.)
Matt Gaetz (Fla.)
Paul Gosar (Ariz.)
Clay Higgins (La.)

The article goes on to state the following:
Both Democratic and Republican leaders in the House supported the ban, with President Biden announcing similar moves against Russian oil on Tuesday.
As we continue to do everything in our power to support the people of Ukraine, we must offer the same compassion to all refugees – regardless of nationality or race.

Scott DesJarlais (Tenn.)
Madison Cawthorn (N.C.)
Bill Posey (Fla.)
Chip Roy (Texas)
Thomas Massie (Ky.)
CLICK HERE for more details share by The Hill.
And if you have the DML NEWS APP, please tell people to download it today and help conservatives have a real voice.
The bill received wide bipartisan support with 414 lawmakers voting in favor of the bill.

The 17 voting against the bill are as follows:
Democrats
Cori Bush (Mo.)
